passage_text: Duties for goods brought into Thailand will be assessed according to Customs Acts, Customs Tariff Decree, and other associated laws. Following are subject to duty charges: 1  Goods which are brought into the country in a limited quantity as personal effects and are not for a commercial purpose. 2  Goods not exceeding 80,000 baht in value. 3  Duties shall be paid in cash on the date of arrival. Thailand Customs General Regulations. 1  Passengers arriving into the Kingdom of Thailand have to fill in the Passenger Declaration Form (Form No. 211) and submit it to the Customs officer while bringing their luggage or belongings through the red or green channel.

131 5 Customs/import duties Introduction Customs/import duties are imposed on some goods that are imported into South Africa. Import duties are imposed to protect local producers. In addition, excise duties are also imposed on selected imported goods.

Import duty & taxes when importing into Thailand. Overview. Import duty and taxes are due when importing goods into Thailand whether by a private individual or a commercial entity. In addition to duty, imports are subject to sales tax (VAT), and in some cases to excise, interior tax and a surcharge. Duty Rates. Duty rates in Thailand vary from 0% to 80%, with an average duty rate of 20.93%. Some products can be imported free of duty, e.g. laptops and other electronic products. Sales Tax. Goods imported into Thailand are subject to VAT at a rate of 7% calculated over the CIF value plus any applicable duty. Minimum thresholds. Imports with a CIF value up to 1000 THB are exempt from duty and VAT

It is important to ensure that an importer has a proper description of goods before the goods are imported into South Africa as the tariff code identified has to be inserted on the customs declaration. The customs duties and VAT payable will be calculated based on the rate of duty dictated by the specific tariff code. Tariff classification of goods is one of the more complex issues under the Customs and Excise Act. Tariff classification relates to the proper classification of goods within the Harmonized Commodity Description and Coding System (tariff book).
